metadata.subject: Criminal Enforcement Redundancy: Oversight of Decisions Not to Prosecute

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
University of Virginia School of Law

relationships.entity_2: University of Virginia School of Law
relationships.description: Author is O. M. Vicars Professor of Law and Barron F. Black Research Professor of Law
Federal prosecutors provide oversight of state prosecutorial decisions through redundant jurisdiction

analysis.purpose: To analyze mechanisms for addressing underenforcement of criminal law, particularly in cases of police violence, sexual assault, and public corruption
analysis.significance: Comprehensive legal analysis of prosecutorial discretion and oversight mechanisms in comparative perspective

notable_quotes: Decisions not to arrest or charge are virtually immune from judicial review or other nonpolitical oversight.
Suspicion of underenforcement is itself a cost, because it reflects a loss of legitimacy for criminal justice institutions.
U.S. jurisdictions are unusual among common law jurisdictions in having abolished private prosecution as a means to vindicate victims' private interests.
red_flags: Systemic underenforcement of sexual assault cases
Racial disparities in police violence cases
Lack of judicial review for prosecutorial declinations

blackmail_indicators.description: No evidence of blackmail or coercion in this academic legal article

illegal_activity.description: This is an academic legal article discussing systemic legal issues, not evidence of first-hand illegal activity

details: References to media coverage of police violence cases
Discussion of public perception and media influence on prosecutorial decisions

public_knowledge.context: Academic legal analysis published in Minnesota Law Review, discussing publicly known issues of prosecutorial discretion and underenforcement

analysis.summary: This legal article analyzes the problem of underenforcement in criminal justice systems, focusing on three areas: public corruption, police violence, and sexual assaults. It examines mechanisms for oversight of prosecutorial discretion including private prosecution, judicial review, and federal-state enforcement redundancy, comparing U.S. approaches with those in other common law and civil law jurisdictions.
